headline: The Masters: Tee times, TV and streaming info for the second round at Augusta National
author: Steve Gardner
sentences:
Second round tee times
(All times Eastern)
8:00 AM: Sandy Lyle, Stewart Hagestad
8:11 AM: Lucas Glover, Erik van Rooyen, Cameron Champ
8:22 AM: Bernhard Langer, Christiaan Bezuidenhout, Cameron Davis
8:33 AM: Charl Schwartzel, Robert MacIntyre, Laird Shepherd

1:52 PM: Hideki Matsuyama, Justin Thomas, James Piot
2:03 PM: Adam Scott, Scottie Scheffler, Tony Finau

Live action from Round 2 from Augusta National can be live streamed at Masters.com, the Masters app and ESPN+ beginning at 8:30 a.m., with the options including featured groups, holes 4, 5, 6, Amen Corner (11th, 12th and 13th holes) and holes 15 and 16.

But lurking just four shots behind in a tie for 10th place is Tiger Woods, playing competitively for the first time since his near-fatal car crash less than 14 months ago,
Woods' last tournament was the November 2020 Masters, won by Dustin Johnson.

Here is all the information you need to get ready for Friday's second round at the 86th Masters at Augusta National Golf Club:
'He's an inspiration to us all':Tiger Woods has magical moments in Masters return | Opinion
Tiger in contention?
Friday's forecast for Augusta, Georgia, calls for cool conditions in the morning, but with an afternoon high of 66 degrees under mostly sunny skies.
Sungjae Im of South Korea opened with a 5-under-par 67 and will take a one-shot lead over Cameron Smith into Friday's second round of the Masters.
Interestingly, the two golfers who tied for second that year – Im and Smith – are once again at the top of the leaderboard.
A Spanish-language simulcast will be broadcast on ESPN Deportes beginning at 3 p.m.
ESPN will broadcast live coverage of the second round from 3 p.m.-7:30 p.m.
Paramount+ will stream second-round highlights beginning at 11:35 p.m.
ET with Sandy Lyle and Stewart Hagestad the first golfers to tee off.
Winds will be out of the WSW at 16 mph, with gusts to 32 mph.
:Opening door for Tiger is never a good idea.
At Augusta National, it's a terrible idea.
